newsitem.title: CHILE: Chile trade surplus slumps to $255 mln Jan-July.
newsitem.headline: Chile trade surplus slumps to $255 mln Jan-July.

text.p: Chile's $142 million trade deficit in July brought its trade balance in the first seven months of the year to $254.7 million, down from $1.47 billion in the first seven months of last year, the Central Bank said.
The July deficit and the widely expected drop in the accumulated surplus were due largely to lower prices on major exports, the Central Bank said in a report.

"The July result is fundamentally the result of the fall in exports, an effect mainly of lower international prices for our products, combined with a moderate but significant rise in imports," said the report.

The slump in export income highlighted Chile's continuing dependence on natural resources, mainly in mining and forestry, for the bulk of its foreign trade income, despite over a decade of solid economic growth.
Exports of copper, by far Chile's number one export, rose slightly last month to $580 million from $556 million in July 1995, Central Bank figures showed.
But the next three largest exports -- paper pulp, fresh fruit and fishmeal -- all plumetted.

Paper pulp, or cellulose, tumbled to $50.8 million last month from $161.4 million in the same month last year. Fresh fruit exports, currently in a seasonal lull, slipped to $22 million from $31 million in July last year.
Fishmeal exports fell to $45 million from $78 million in July last year, the bank reported.

Imports for the first seven months of the year came to $9.24 billion, up sharply from $7.99 billion in the same period of 1995, while total exports rose narrowly to $9.48 billion from $9.46 billion in the first seven months of last year.

July figures showed imports higher in most categories. Consumer good imports rose to $279 million from $239 million in July last year, while capital goods imports rose to $431.4 million from $246 million in July last year.
